title: Recent contributions to the historical geography of the Hittite empire
Charles Burney, after graduating in history and archaeology and anthropology from King’s College, Cambridge, gained wide firsthand experience of Near Eastern archaeology on excavations in Egypt

After carrying out extensive archaeological surveys in northern and eastern Turkey, he was appointed to a junior post in the University of Manchester, thereafter as senior lecturer in Near Eastern archaeology. He has directed excavations in northwestern Iran as well as at a site in the territory of the Iron Age kingdom of Urartu (Ararat) in eastern Turkey, where one of his former students has until recently been directing excavation of a major Urartian fortress beside Lake Van. From 1954 he carried out his archaeological reconnaissances by bicycle over nontarmac roads for three years and later by Land Rover. The acquisition of a reasonable command of spoken Turkish was essential, not least in the villages

container-title: 1987 the first annual conference was held in Manchester of the British Association for Near Eastern Archaeology (BANEA), which he founded in order to protect the inclusion of Near Eastern archaeology in UK universities
note: After 30 years, this is now well established, having developed considerably, with conferences at different universities every year, now in early January.
title: In Manchester, his philosophy as a teacher was to provide his B.A. students with a broad view in both time and space, from Turkey, the Caucasus, and Iran to Egypt, the Levant, and Iraq and from the Neolithic period until ca.500 BC. This approach is no longer very fashionable in a time of increasing specialization

container-title: and in a cottage beside the sea in the Isle of Skye, with his wife
title: Married in 1960, with twins now in their forties, he lives in the United Kingdom
